Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: What sustainable or environmental practices have been implemented?
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result: Throughout the text, there are several examples of sustainable or environmental practices that have been implemented. One example is SmartCity Solutions, which provides digital solutions for the waste management industry. By doing so, they aim to minimize waste, conserve resources, and promote more efficient waste management systems. Additionally, ChopValue takes waste materials like wood chips and turns them into valuable products such as furniture, reducing waste and promoting circular economies. These two companies demonstrate a commitment to sustainability and environmental stewardship through their innovative approaches to managing waste and repurposing discarded materials.

Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: Are there any events or initiatives focused on environmental conservation? If yet then list 10 such events.
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result:
Yes, there are numerous events and initiatives focused on environmental conservation. However, providing a comprehensive list of all such events would not be feasible within the given constraints. Instead, here are ten examples of notable events and initiatives related to environmental conservation:

1. Earth Day (April 22)
2. United Nations Climate Change Conferences (held every few years)
3. World Environment Day (June 5th)
4. COP26 (United Nations Climate Change Conference, scheduled for late 22)
5. Global Landscapes Forum (held annually since 22)
6. World Wildlife Fund (WWF) Annual Conservation Awards
7. International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) World Conservation Congress
8. Our Planet Netflix documentary series (raising awareness about environmental issues)
9. Extinction Rebellion protests and campaigns
10. Greenpeace international campaigns and events

We also do other projects and products ranging from store displays and tabletops for our B2B clients as well as sustainable home decor and work-from-home solutions for our B2C customers  Aziz Do you feel like you’ve developed a new ‘circular economy’ business model for urban environments Bock To be honest circular economy is a term I only really started understanding after I founded ChopValue To me being resource efficient with the use of our natural resources was always the goal in my career But as our concept has grown we have indeed created a circular economy concept that adds value to already existing resources in our cities without having to use any virgin materials from our natural forests I like to think that we don’t just add value to resources as our franchise concept also allows franchisees and local professionals working in the trades to benefit and have impact in their community Aziz What are the cities you’re targeting for expansion and how can people work with you

Financials & Funding.question: Are there any investor events or funding rounds? If yes then list them.
Financials & Funding.result:
Based on the provided information, I cannot provide specific details about investor events or funding rounds related to the mentioned companies. However, I can suggest some general resources where you might find such information:

1. Crunchbase (<https://www.crunchbase.com/>) - A popular database for tracking startup funding, mergers, and acquisitions. You can search for companies and track their funding history.
2. AngelList (<https://angel.co/>) - An online platform connecting startups with angel investors, venture capitalists, and other funding sources. You can browse companies raising funds and follow their progress.
3. Startup events calendar (e.g., Techvibes, Eventbrite) - Keep an eye on local and national startup events, conferences, and pitch competitions where founders often seek funding and network with potential investors.
4. Industry-specific websites and newsletters - Subscribe to relevant newsletters or follow industry-specific websites to stay updated on investor events, funding announcements, and trends within your area of interest.

This month we uncover the next 10 innovators to watch as part of our Futures  Awards which highlight those brands businesses and people innovating for change – and a better future Who are the Futures  Innovators  Curated by The Future Laboratory our Futures  Innovators is an annual longlist of  disruptors and change-makers  From our selection of  Innovators a peer-reviewed shortlist of 10 individuals to watch plus an award to the winner will be announced in October  at our London Trend Briefing event  Each month we spotlight 10 brands businesses and people from around the world who are seeking to drive change across 10 key sectors Each month we profile 10 brands businesses and people that our team of researchers and analysts have identified as driving forward innovation We look at change-makers agitating across multiple categories including beauty wellness luxury design retail and travel In October  our complete Futures  Innovators list will be presented to a panel of industry judges

Let’s look at a handful of rounds that may have been overlooked but have tech that deserves a second read-through We all snag the takeout chopsticks on our way out of our favorite Chinese or sushi place when getting takeout But after using them how many of us toss them in the trash Canada-based ChopValue is here to help with some of our environmentally unfriendly eating habits The startup raised 77 million in new funding to support its network of waste-to-resource microfactories ChopValue already has saved more than  million chopsticks from the landfill — turning what we usually use to shovel lo mein into our mouths into sustainably made decor kitchen accessories and other products The company plans to use the new cash to get into new markets in Asia Pacific and Europe It already is piloting its microfactories in US cities such as Las Vegas and Boston While ChopValue has started with chopsticks the company’s model can be used for other types of reuse It kind of sounds like something

agitating across multiple categories including beauty wellness luxury design retail and travel In October  our complete Futures  Innovators list will be presented to a panel of industry judges who will select their 10 leading innovators Our March longlist looks at haircare scientists African luxurians and TikTok journalists shaping the future You can nominate your own innovator here Candace Harris is using science to make the future of haircare inclusive The Atlanta-based computer scientist created innovative hair analysis tool Myavana the first AI system to properly recognise multi-textured hair Myavana made its debut at CES in  and its process is simple and intuitive users take a photo of their hair and upload it to the Myavana app which then analyses their unique hair type and recommends products and styles Myavana also provides personalised haircare evaluation with its Hair Strand Analysis Kit which involves consumers sending a strand of their hair to Myavana for examination in

Yes, there are several ongoing and upcoming research projects and innovation initiatives related to the mentioned companies and events. Here's a brief list:

1. ChopValue - Continuous development of their waste-to-resource microfactories and expansion into new markets.

Toward the end of this month the Zero Waste Conference hits Vancouver and will showcase some of the city’s innovative startups disrupting the clean technology space Presented by Metro Vancouver and the National Zero Waste Council the theme of this year’s event is “A Future Without Waste Regenerative and Waste-Free by Design” The two-day event will focus on how entrepreneurs are adapting to address today’s economic ecological and social challenges Organizers say the event is a resource for both businesses and investors highlighting new economic opportunities and innovations from those on the forefront of the circular economy Taking place September 28 and 29 the Zero Waste Conference features some notable local startups We highlight a handful below ChopValue is the brainchild of Felix Böck a former UBC doctoral student in the faculty of forestry who studied bamboo as a building material The sustainability brand designs and manufactures circular economy products made entirely of recycled

Firstly, ChopValue received $77 million in new funding to support their network of waste-to-resource microfactories. Secondly, Moment Energy won the K grand prize as the winner of Spring Activator's first-ever National Impact Investor Challenge and claimed the third place prize package in the New Ventures BC Competition.

the venture capital arm of the Central Intelligence Agency is an investor A list like this is legally mandated to include at least one startup using generative AI so let’s look at legal AI startup Harvey The company raised an undisclosed round at a  million valuation this month led by Sequoia Capital according to a report by Insider While not much has been reported about that round Harvey did announce a 5 million seed round led by OpenAI Startup Fund last November — when AI was just starting to take off — so it did not take long to raise another round from a big-name investor even in a down market Instead of using AI for sales or marketing purposes the San Francisco-based startup is putting it to work for lawyers giving them an interface to use AI in editing legal documents or performing legal research Now the only question is What is Harvey’s hourly rate Many of us shovel food scraps down our sink’s garbage disposal with most thinking it just disappears into the ether Well the sad

Collaboration & Partnerships.result: From the provided text, it seems that the main objective of these collaborations is to create a positive impact in the community through sustainable practices. These partnerships aim to promote circular economy principles, reduce waste, and minimize carbon footprints. By working together towards common goals, they hope to achieve tangible results such as reducing landfill waste, conserving natural resources, and creating job opportunities within local communities. Additionally, these collaborations may also focus on raising awareness about environmental issues and inspiring others to adopt more sustainable practices. Overall, the desired outcome of these collaborations is to collectively contribute to a greener, more sustainable future for everyone.
